Americas First Balloon Ascent
January 9, 1793 • Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, U.S.A.
Hot air ballooning
USA
20c
JAN
9
1984
19104
8

International Tributes to the History of Flisht
Americas First Balloon Ascent.
On the morning of January 9, 1793, a large crowd of
anxious spectators gathered behind Independence
Hall in Philadelphia. Among them was the President
of the United States, George Washington. They had
come to witness a moment of history, the first bal-
loon ascent in America.
At 10:00 a.m., Jean-Pierre Blanchard, dressed in a
plain blue suit and a cocked hat with white feathers,
lifted off. He covered some 15 miles before coming
down in Woodbury, New Jersey. Then, aided by a
handwritten letter of introduction from Washington,
Blanchard found his way back to Philadelphia. Resi-
dents of that city gave him a hero's welcome.
The full-color cachet portrays the moment of take-
off, as it was described in detail the following day by
The Federal Gazette and Philadelphia Daily Advertiser.
Mint stamp: The mint stamp on this Cover was issued
by the United States in 1983 to commemorate the
200th anniversary of manned flight. It pictures color-
ful modern sport balloons, typically made of nylon or
polyester, which are filled with hot air.
Postmark: This Cover was postmarked in Philadel-
phia, Pennsylvania on January 9, 1984, the anniver-
sary of the first balloon ascent in America.
© Postal Commemorative Society
Printed in U.S.A.
1015.054.004
properties.sfomuseum:description: Airmail flight cover, part of International Tributes to the History of Flight series by the Postal Commemorative Society; white envelope with full color illustration cachet and inset stamp commemorating America’s first balloon ascent on January 9, 1793, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, U.S.A., by Jean-Pierre Blanchard with hot-air balloon; cancellation stamp dated January 9, 1984 in Philadelphia; includes information on reverse.
